bioghist.p: Father Joseph Anthony Flaherty (1916-1993) was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Flaherty attended the Gesu Parochial School, Saint Joseph’s Preparatory School, and in 1938 received an A.B. degree from Saint Joseph’s College in Philadelphia. In 1940 he began his theological studies at Augustinian College, Washington, D.C. During the summer months he took graduate courses at the nearby Catholic University of America. Flaherty was ordained to the priesthood in 1943. In 1946 he was granted a Master’s degree, and in 1949 a Ph.D., in English from Harvard University. In 1947 Father Flaherty was assigned to the newly opened Merrimack College in North Andover, Massachusetts, as a teacher of English. From 1951 to 1964 he held the position of director of the Part-time Division of the College. In 1964 he was transferred to Villanova University and appointed Vice President for Academic Affairs. In the following year, 1965, he was appointed president of the University, serving until 1967. During his tenure as president the entire curriculum of the university was made available to women students; the construction of the first residence hall for women was begun; and salaries for the faculty were raised. In 1967 Father Flaherty returned to Merrimack College as a professor of English and continued to teach until he retired in the mid-1980s.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Father Joseph A. Flaherty. Materials include: correspondence relating to the Master Plan for Higher Education (1967), commencements (1966-1967), a University Library addition (1966-1967), and other topics; clippings on Father Flaherty's appointments as Vice President of Academic Affairs and as President; a report on the Academic Addition to the School of Law; legal materials related to several Villanova estates; and a sermon given at the Baccalaureate Mass in 1966. The collection also includes a small amount of correspondence of Rev. Robert J. Welsh, mostly relating to his inaugural service and a Pontifical Mass, both in September of 1967.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
